:Not to be confused with [[CEng]] (the [[Post-nominal letters|post-nominal]] for

 representing a procession of singers and musicians in the honor of the Monthu
 at Medamoud.]] The 'Ã§eng' is a Turkish harp. It was a popular Ottoman
 instrument until the last quarter of the 17th century. The word comes from the
 Persian word "chang," which means "harp" (and also "five fingers").


The ancestor of the Ottoman harp is thought to be an instrument seen in ancient
Assyrian tablets. While a similar instrument also appears in Egyptian drawings.

In the late 20th century, instrument makers and performers began to revive the
Ã§eng, with newer designs incorporating advanced tuning mechanisms such as those
found on the [[kanun (instrument)|kanun]]. Tone bending is also possible, by
pressing on the string behind the bridge. Whereas the soundbox on the old Ã§eng
was on the upper part of the instrument, modern instruments have the soundbox on
the lower part.

In 1995, Fikret Karakaya, a [[Kemenche|kemenÃ§e]] player from Turkey, made a Ã§eng
using the descriptions in the masnavi "Ãengname" by the Turkish poet Ahmed-i
Dai, and from Iranian and Ottoman miniatures from the 15th and 16th centuries.
He presently plays and records with the instrument.

The second Ã§eng in Turkey was recently made by Mehmet
Soylemez, an instrument maker and master's degree graduate student at Istanbul
Technical University, for Åirin PancaroÄlu, the primary harpist of Turkey. She
has started to explore this ancient instrument and will soon record with it.

In the United States, New England Conservatory of Music ethnomusicology
professor Robert Labaree plays and records with the instrument.

The Ã§eng belongs to the family of instruments known in organology as "open
harps," which are further divided into the "bow harps" and the "square harps."
The Ã§eng is in the latter groups.

Of the square harps used for 2,500 years in not only the Middle East but in
Central Asia and the Far East as well, the Ottoman Ã§eng was the last to fall
into disuse.

The father of the Ottoman Ã§eng, which in Ottoman poetry was a metaphor for one
in love doubled over in agony from a lover's cruelty, was the Iranian Ã§eng. But
in Istanbul, the instrument gained certain features. Writers such as SafiyÃ¼ddin
UrmevÃ® (-1294) and Abd al-Qadir Maraghi (1350-60-1435) gave detailed information
on the Ã§eng. The Persian manuscript, KenzÃ¼'t-Tuhaf, written in the 14th century,
gives a good deal of information on the Ã§eng. But the poetical work of the 15th-
century poet Ahmed-i DÃ¢Ã® titled Ãengname put the Ã§eng in a very privileged place
among the other Ottoman instruments. This was because no such work had ever been
written - poetically or prosaically - about any other Ottoman instrument.
Besides the "market paintings," which were made by folk painters outside the
palace for European travelers, most of which are to day in European museums,
there are many miniatures depicting the Ã§eng along with other instruments, in
albums such as the Sehinsahname, the SÃ¼leymanname, the Album of Ahmed I and the
SurnÃ¢me-i HÃ¼mÃ¢yÃ»n. A careful examination of these reveals the following:

1. The Ã§eng was played by both men and women.
2. Miniatures depicting the Ã§eng show it accompanying talks by poets and learned
   men than on the stage.
3. Though it is difficult to speak of a standard size of Ã§eng, it becomes clear
   that there were two sizes of the instrument. The first, the "kucak Ã§engi"
   (lap Ã§eng) was small and played indoors, seated. The second was the "aÃ§Ä±k
   hava Ã§engi", which was quite large and played standing up. The kucak Ã§engi
   was played with the pegboard on the player's left knee; the aÃ§Ä±k hava Ã§engi
   rested on a long foot that went between the player's legs, and tied around
   the waist by a belt attached to the lower part of its body (that is, the
   resonator).
4. The Ã§eng's resonator was constructed in two ways, either curved or straight.
   While the curved resonator is encountered in Iranian, Arab, Uygur, Chinese
   and even Japanese miniatures, the straight resonator appears only in Ottoman
   miniatures.

Possibly, when the Ottomans adopted the Ã§eng that came from Iran, another closed
harp descended from the Phoenician harp was in use in the Byzantine period.
After the Iranian-derived Ottoman Ã§eng was abandoned, the above mentioned
triangular harp was in use in Istanbul, especially in some homes in the Pera
district. The fact that in miniatures this instrument, which we can claim was
never played in the palace, is shown in the hands of women in palace attire, is
not difficult to explain. The market painters were not like the palace artists,
who were closely familiar with palace life. For this reason, elements of palace
life were mixed with those of outside life.
